title: What is the Leonard Cohen song 'Hallelujah' about? - Quora

response.answer_text: Disclaimer: I’m not a literary expert. I haven’t read most of the other answers, or any other theories about the song, so this is just my own interpretation, most of it probably wrong. Like brain surgery, literary theory is probably best left to the experts. The most obvious themes are Judaism and, like most of Cohen’s oeuvre, romantic love, with, again typically, a sort of nostalgic, “broken”, feel. This is a very good song, with a few points perhaps hammered home a bit too overtly but no words that really don’t need to be there. It’s an exploration of individuals’ futile search for meaning in love, words, and religion. Cohen was both a Jew and a Buddhist, and of course a Canadian which meant he was also steeped in a western post-Christian culture. He often incorporates “Christianised” ideas of his Jewish tradition. Of course, Christians recognise the Jewish Bible as their “Old Testament”. Generally, Cohen’s raison d’etre, if one was to believe in such things, seems to have been to suffer, but much more slowly than Isaiah’s suffering servant, and not so much to hold a candle as to remind us that darkness is not a thing in itself but just a low amount of light. Romantically, Cohen generally seems to see love as the desire to be fully alive, to find some deeper meaning in the struggle and futility of it all, a desire that is ultimately futile but more important than anything else. Maybe he got this idea from his long struggle with depression, maybe he got it from his Buddhism, or maybe he got it from being human and introspective. Cohen reportedly once said he never married because he wasn’t brave enough. Relationships are one of the most primal drives and, like life itself, often don’t work out quite as we intended. Leonard Cohen is the poet of brokenness, not in the gauche Christian sense of providing a fix, but in the sense of reminding us that this is what life is about. Hollywood tells us that really living is what other people do; poets like Cohen remind us that you and me, simple, struggling, broken, people, are real people, and our lives are real lives. “There is a crack in everything, that’s how the light gets in,” he says in another song. Still, our desire for spirituality is quite primal, and Cohen often conflates love and religion in his songs. This is actually a very Christian idea, but also one that’s popular in other traditions such as Hinduism. Perhaps Cohen is aware that in Christianity, the marriage relationship is explicitly understood as a metaphor of the relationship between humans and the divine (in fundamentalist terms, the relationship between “God” and the “believers”, but of course Cohen isn’t into simplistic certainties). He draws out this metaphor almost too explicitly in this song. Let’s look at the lyrics line by line: Now I've heard there was a secret chordThat David played, and it pleased the Lord This is a very clear reference to a story in the Jewish Bible (Christian “Old Testament”) which you can read here: 1 Samuel 16:14-23 I’m kind of surprised that Cohen doesn’t reference King David more often in other places. David was a very Cohenesque kind of hero. He is of course one of the greatest Biblical heroes in Judaism, and even in Christianity. In many ways he’s thought of as the founder of ancient Israel as an orderly Kingdom. He is attributed with writing most of the Psalms—the books of poetry in the Bible. But he’s also a very broken hero. He murdered, lied, disobeyed clear commandments from his God, committed adultery, married multiple women, and engaged in bloody wars for personal gain. Note that Cohen changes the Biblical myth quite a bit, to make it more palatable. He isn’t into taking these things too literally. But you don't really care for music, do you? It’s not clear what he means here. Perhaps he’s addressing the imaginary lover in the song. Or perhaps it’s the idea that we all feel there is something more to music, like love, that we miss out on. Perhaps he’s just grumpy that maybe his song would not be recognised (it wasn’t, for ten years). It goes like this, the fourth, the fifthThe minor fall, the major liftThe baffled king composing "Hallelujah" I don’t understand the chord sequence so I googled for it and Rolling Stone (How Leonard Cohen's 'Hallelujah' Brilliantly Mingled Sex, Religion) says it’s quite literally the structure of the song, and most pop songs. It also points out that a minor key is considered less “happy” than a major key. “Hallelujah” is of course a word that religious people use to express a sense of awe at what they perceive as God. It’s a very common word in the Psalms, which as mentioned above are attributed to David. On his death, Cohen was described as “one of the most explicitly Jewish popular songwriters since the ancient King David, whose Psalms he expertly imitated” (Leonard Cohen's 5 most Jewish songs). It’s a visceral word that you might liken to “wow!”. Sometimes we just want to say “yes!” to life, with no real words, because there is nothing interesting to say but yet life still is … broken, happy, sad, disappointing, amazing, boring, it’s all those things and more and all you can say is “oh”, or “wow”, or, in religious terms, “hallelujah” (literally “praise Yahweh”). When David played his harp in this story, he was not yet king, he was a peasant shepherd boy. He played for the King, who was mentally ill. David later became king. Supposedly he had already had a prophecy that this would happen, which might have been why he was “baffled”, or more probably, as a songwriter like Cohen, he might have found life itself baffling. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah Your faith was strong but you needed proof Only people who miss the cadences and mystery of life have blind faith. Not Cohen and not, at least in his imagination, King David (who in reality might never have existed, but let’s not go there) You saw her bathing on the roofHer beauty and the moonlight overthrew you Later in King David’s life when he is rich and the king over a united Kingdom of Israel (a rare thing), he gets careless with his power, and sees a Bathsheeba, a married woman, bathing on the roof. We don’t know if she was beautiful but obviously Cohen, who appreciates beautiful women, would imagine she was, and perhaps he imagines it as happening in moonlight because it’s a very imperfect union, lit, but not by what we would consider perfect light. King David’s lust for this woman leads him to murder her husband, but out of their marriage comes King Solomon, another great hero, and generations later, Jesus. You can read the Biblical version of that story here; 2 Samuel 11-12 She tied you to a kitchen chairShe broke your throne and she cut your hairAnd from your lips she drew the Hallelujah Here Cohen is purposefully conflating two Bible stories. He’s continuing on in the story of David and Bathsheba. As you could see in the second half of the story in the Bible that I linked to, David’s murder and adultery (in the Jewish Bible “adultery” is seen more as the “sin” of a man stealing another man’s wife, rather than his breaking any marriage vows to his own wives) had serious repercussions (karma?) for him personally, but also for his kingdom. The Kingdom was split during the reign of David’s grandson, Rehoboam the son of Solomon. Perhaps that’s why Cohen refers to Bathsheba breaking his throne. But David’s kingdom was often threatened, particularly by another son from another wife. There’s no mention of him being tied to a kitchen chair, but perhaps Cohen is throwing in a modern-day reference, how marriage ties you to mundane life in a house with a kitchen. But then Cohen clearly conflates the story of Samson and Delilah, which is set much earlier in the Biblical myth. This is the Bible’s ultimate femme fatale story, with the David and Bathsheba story probably a close second. Samson was a powerful superhero and a kind of warlord before the Israelites became a kingdom. His superpower was superhuman strength. As well as that he was a brilliant warrior and went around slaughtering the indigenous people with glee. But Samson had an Achilles’ heel. His strength was conditional on his promise to the god Yahweh, and Samson’s end of the bargain was that he must never cut his hair. Eventually, predictably, Delilah tricks him into revealing his secret and his hair is cut and he ends his life as a blind slave, eventually committing suicide. The femme fatale aspect of the story is hammered home way too obviously in the Bible, so Cohen only hints at the story. You can read the whole story in the Bible here: Judges 13-16 The reference to femme fatales shouldn’t need more explanation. Cohen’s take on this is that they still draw the “Hallelujah”. Love, even if it’s broken and ends badly, makes us say “yes” to life. You might find this, or some of Cohen’s other writings about women, somewhat sexist, but I think he is simply writing from his point of view and not expecting us to take any poetry or myth, including the Bible, as literal truth about anything except what it feels like to be alive. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah Now Cohen switches from the Biblical myth to a more concrete discussion about love. He also seems to switch from addressing a man (symbolised by King David) to a woman). Baby I have been here beforeI know this room, I've walked this floorI used to live alone before I knew you “Baby” acts as a transition signal. It’s not the way you address a famous king. Even in common use, it’s a word that trivialises romantic relationships. Cohen wrote this song when he was fifty. Talking, perhaps, to an imaginary lover, he tells her that he knows how this goes. He’s done it before. It never quite works out, but life and love are Sisyphean, are they not? or, would be, if life wasn’t so short. And of course we all used to live alone before we met our partner, either literally or metaphorically, and perhaps still do, metaphorically.I've seen your flag on the marble arch I didn’t understand this line, but some googling tells me that “Marble Arch” is a famous statue in London that commemorates the British defeat of Napoleon. It’s based on the Arc de Triomph, and the Arch of Constantine. Again, Cohen sometimes uses sexist imagery of love as a man “conquering” a woman. Perhaps though if he was a woman he’s use different imagery and as a poet is entitled to tell us how he feels about it.Love is not a victory marchIt's a cold and it's a broken Hallelujah This kind of offsets the “conquering” metaphor of the previous line. But should love be like a victory march? Perhaps we all feel that it should, but it ends up being “broken” (a favourite word of Cohen’s) and surprisingly cold. But still something that makes us say “yes” to life. Some recordings of this song have love as a “lonely” hallelujah, rather than “broken”. Both make sense. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah There was a time you let me knowWhat's really going on belowBut now you never show it to me, do you? Now Cohen talks about love gone bad. After all, he already told us that he knows that’s how it will end, and even before it goes bad it’s ultimately unsatisfactory. Perhaps the first two lines are a fairly crude description of sex that has lost its adventure. Cohen isn’t above using fairly explicit descriptions of sex in his songs. But also these words are deliciously ambiguous and could be thought of as talking directly to God. Does God show us what’s really going on down here on earth? Perhaps there are moments, such as when we fall in love, when we feel like he does, and that last line could apply either to Cohen’s imagining of God, or to a lover.And remember when I moved in youThe holy dove was moving too Again this is probably purposefully ambiguous. It’s probably meant to invoke both the Christian idea of God’s Holy Spirit, and a description of sex. Both of course are further metaphors for the changes we make in our lover’s lives and the depth of connectedness we have with them. The second line seems to explicitly say that he means both. The “Holy Ghost” or the “Holy Spirit” is a Christian idea, not really found so explicitly in Judaism, of God’s actual spirit that works in people’s minds. Nevertheless, theologically, it does tie back to the David story. Note too that Cohen changes the name from the “Holy Ghost” to “holy dove”, which is less offensive to Judaism, and invokes the idea of Noah, but is still recognisably Christian (because Christians symbolise the Holy Ghost as a dove). The dove represents peace, and in the Noah story represented the hope in the search for life after everything had been destroyed.And every breath we drew was Hallelujah Again, the explicit message of the song. There are moments that take our breath away, and although they are empty and broken, they are what life is about. Actually, life is about those moments and all the other moments too. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah You say I took the name in vainI don't even know the nameBut if I did, well really, what's it to you?There's a blaze of light in every wordIt doesn't matter which you heardThe holy or the broken Hallelujah The Hebrew Bible made a big deal about the name of God, which in English we usually render as “LORD” or “Jehovah” or more properly, “Yahweh”. Etymologically, it’s the “jah” in “hallelujah”. Jews, as you probably know, were so scared about taking that name in vain that nobody said it and so everybody forgot how to pronounce it. Hebrew only writes the vowels, so we know they were Y/J, H, W, H, but we don’t know what the vowel sounds were. The name of God was the centre of the putative special relationship between God and his chosen people. But they forgot the name, and now Cohen, a Jew, doesn’t even know the name. Did Cohen take the name of love in vain by loving so many women and having meaningless sex with others? But he doesn’t even know the name, because like all of us we don’t know how to love properly. Again, it’s a metaphor for love. Or maybe love is a metaphor for religion. Or maybe both are metaphors. But then every word has a blaze of light in it. Because every word is a way to communicate, to recognise the spark of humanity in each other. And since broken, imperfect, things are holy to Cohen too, this means that every word is sacred, as you’d expect of a wordsmith. Every word, holy, or broken. Every love, holy or broken. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah Maybe there's a God aboveBut all I've ever learned from loveWas how to shoot somebody who outdrew youAnd it's not a cry that you hear at nightIt's not somebody who's seen the lightIt's a cold and it's a broken Hallelujah In case we didn’t get it in the first five stanzas, Cohen reminds us again that love is a metaphor for God (or, I would say, God is a metaphor for love). But he has a cynical view of love, again as a kind of battle. Perhaps towards the end of the song he talks about the end of relationships. Who initiates the breakup? It’s like a shootout. But all parts of love, and life, are not “Eureka!” moments, nor the excited babblings of a convert (“seen the light” is an explicitly Christian phrase, because conversion in Judaism or Buddhism are much slower and procedural). It’s cold, and it’s broken, but it’s still something that makes you say “yes” to life. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah I did my best, it wasn't much Is he talking about life here, or love?I couldn't feel, so I tried to touch We can’t really feel all the poignancy of life like we really want to, so we try to touch each other, with words and sex. Ultimately they’re cold and broken too, but we must try.I've told the truth, I didn't come to fool youAnd even though it all went wrongI'll stand before the Lord of Song The Lord of Song is a Jewish and Christian phrase referring to God. Again it’s attributed to David, and again it gives primacy to poetry. Again, words are the other way we search for poignancy and connection. Of all the hundreds of descriptions for God in the Old Testament, perhaps “Lord of Song” attracts Cohen, the wordsmith and singer, most. The idea that we will stand before God and be judged for our life is again something that’s not emphasised, or believed at all, in most forms of Judaism and makes no sense in Buddhism. But it’s a Christian idea. No doubt Cohen doesn’t believe that this would actually happen. But it’s a useful way to think about our life. Even at fifty, one begins to look back over one’s life and try to evaluate it. And if it was empty and broken, will it pass?With nothing on my tongue but Hallelujah If Cohen’s life were to be judged by some imaginary God, he feels that he wouldn’t have much to show. Love and life were cold and broken. He felt like he never quite lived as poignantly as we were meant to. But all he’ll have is the “hallelujah”, the memory of the times he said “yes” to life, even if it all went wrong at the end. That’s all you can do, that’s all you can have, and anything else is just fooling yourself. Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah Cohen said he sees it as a hopeful song. I don’t think he meant that in the sense that Judaism or love have “the answer”, or that we can even have a religion or a love that is not fundamentally broken. Rather, I think he meant that there are these tenuous moments when the light gets in, and that is, in a quiet way, hopeful. In the end, Cohen uses more imagery from the Judao-Christian tradition of the religion he remained in and which was his heritage. However, it’s somewhat disparaging. Theistic answers are too simple, as is like the Hollywood message that “true love” is the answer. In the end, Buddhism is closer to our experience of life, when all we have is a brief dance around sunyata (emptiness) and our most poignant moments (falling in love) are dhuka. This is a song that uses Judaism as a starting point but does not find its answers in Judaism, nor anywhere else. Cohen was a poet and knows that all we have is the questions.

This song seems rather confusing, precisely because it deals with dualities in life, good/bad, love/loss, faith/fear, and yet at the end it comes back to reaffirm that despite its imperfections, life is wonderful, and it goes on. The text here is from his version, but some people have reported that he wrote, and on different occasions sang, up to 80 verses, so there apparently is no definitive text. Though this version does not emphasize love, some of the versions, depending on the verses they choose, definitely do. Many other singers have covered this song, and most of those use at least some different verses. When they choose those verses, they can also put emphasis on happiness or sadness and loss, or life and love, depending on those particular verses. There is no clear, one interpretation on the meaning of this song, because, like many works of art, it is deep and complex and means different things to different people, but let's start with some common meanings that are attributed to it: First, understand what is the primary word here: Hallelujah, which essentially means, "Glory to God," or, "Praise be to God." But it can also mean, in a more vernacular way, "Life is amazing," or other, similar things. The way it is used in this song is really just as a word that is an affirmation of life, ALL of life. Cohen himself said he chose that word because it means so much in so many ways. In other words, it is a word of awe, of inspiration, of gratitude and of praise, and many many other things. In some cases it can even be a word of sarcasm or scorn, but in the end, it returns to praise and wonder. Far from being a "filler" word, it is really the core word of the whole song, and it is repeated 33 times in the song. Every verse ends in the word Hallelujah, and each of those Hallelujahs is different. Now I've heard there was a secret chordThat David played, and it pleased the LordBut you don't really care for music, do you?It goes like thisThe fourth, the fifthThe minor fall, the major liftThe baffled king composing Hallelujah [Who is he talking to here? Someone who he cares about. He essentially is saying, "The Lord," was pleased by the musician "Kind David's" efforts, but "you, the person he cares about" aren't so impressed by his efforts, are you. He implies that he is David, trying to find the ‘secret chord’ so that he can get understanding in love. Since it isn’t working he tries to explain what he is doing, and how he is doing it, but he realizes that he is the baffled king, and that he really can never truly get his meaning across. He understands that he is incapable of the full communication he wants. In the end it is okay because things are amazing, anyway.] HallelujahHallelujahHallelujahHallelujah Your faith was strong but you needed proofYou saw her bathing on the roofHer beauty and the moonlight overthrew youShe tied you to a kitchen chairShe broke your throne, and she cut your hairAnd from your lips she drew the Hallelujah [In this second verse he is talking to himself, the point of view character. First line refers to his overall faith, belief and confidence, but also his doubts. He believes in love, but is wary of the pain. Second and third lines refer to surprising, amazing things, including how helpless we sometimes are before the beauty of life. Fourth and fifth lines conflate the stories of King David and Samson, and allude to the calamities that fell upon King David and Samson, and these lines talk about the curves that life or love, or hope, can send our way. It also illustrates how painful and prickly love can be, and how love leads us to surrender some part of ourselves, in order to maintain it, but in the end, it is still wonderful and we can't help but cry, "Hallelujah." If strictly interpreted as talking about love, he is wistful about the wonderful act of falling in love, but also emphasizes that the ones we love can hurt us the most. In the 4th and 5th lines, his lover came back to hurt him, perhaps not intentionally, yet he still finds love amazing.] Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah You say I took the name in vainI don't even know the nameBut if I did, well really, what's it to you?There's a blaze of lightIn every wordIt doesn't matter which you heardThe holy or the broken Hallelujah [In the third verse he is speaking again to the person he wants to understand him. And he is also speaking to himself. In the first and second lines, there is more insecurity and the realization that there is a lack of understanding from the person he is speaking to. Whether that is someone else who doesn’t understand, or even lack of self understanding. Third line essentially affirms that he really would like praise and acceptance, but in the end, he is his own, strong, independent person. Fourth, fifth and sixth lines talk again about the wonder, and the dichotomies of life, and that it is all good. In the end, whether it is holy and perfect or broken and incomplete, it is all still amazing. Interpreted as love, this is his affirmation that he does love, but he doesn't completely understand what love is. Meanwhile, he isn't sure his lover loves him back. Yet even so, love is still incredible, and whether it is perfect or imperfect, it is still amazing.] Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah I did my best, it wasn't muchI couldn't feel, so I tried to touchI've told the truth, I didn't come to fool youAnd even though it all went wrongI'll stand before the Lord of SongWith nothing on my tongue but Hallelujah [Last verse shows that he, the point of view person, realizes that his efforts are meager, they will never be enough, but he has a core of honesty and character, and that even though his efforts will never be enough, they were still worthwhile, and deserving of respect, and acceptance. And if others won’t accept him, then he will accept himself. Still talking about the quandary of love and communications between people, he explains how he tried to communicate his love, and when words weren't enough, he tried to show it with physical actions, but in the end, it still wasn't enough. Yet he has no regrets.] Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah [Two verses that are not in the original Cohen recording, but which are in many of the other recorded versions, especially by other singers, are listed below. Obviously, these verses focus much more on the bittersweetness of love and loss.] "Baby I've been here beforeI've seen this room and I've walked the floorI used to live alone before I knew yaBut I've seen your flag on the marble archOur love is not a victory marchIt's a cold and it's a broken Hallelujah Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah Maybe there's a God aboveBut all I've ever learned from loveWas how to shoot somebody who outdrew yaIt's not a cry that you hear at nightIt's not someone who's seen the lightIt's a cold and broken Hallelujah Hallelujah, HallelujahHallelujah, Hallelujah..." In the end, Cohen himself said, "There is a religious Hallelujah, but there are many other ones. When one looks at the world and his proper life there's only one thing to say, it is 'Hallelujah.'"  "The Hallelujah, the David's Hallelujah, was still a religious song. So I wanted to indicate that Hallelujah can come out of things that have nothing to do with religion." "And then I realized there is a Hallelujah more general that we speak to the world, to life."

I think the song has two different meanings layered into the same lyrics. The first and most obvious meaning is recounting the biblical story of the rise and fall of of King David. Cohen used this I think as a way to express his own issues with women and sex - he was a well known womaniser who had issues sustaining a relationship - so the biblical story of David is a reference - a metaphor to express that. Thus it has both a personal meaning relating to Cohen’s own life - and a divine metaphysical interpretation related to the biblical story as well. The early parts of the song clearly trace the story of King David as a young shepherd boy playing his harp to sooth the spirit of the afflicted King Saul. Here through David’s holy and righteous life - David finds favour with the lord and receives his holy spirit. Many people think the latter sections of the song then switches to another biblical story and refers to story of Samson because of the “hair” reference but I don’t think its meant that way. The other verses all clearly refer to King David’s story and I believe these lines do as well. Your faith was strong but you needed proofYou saw her bathing on the roofHer beauty and the moonlight overthrew yaShe tied you to a kitchen chairShe broke your throne, and she cut your heirAnd from your lips she drew the hallelujah You will notice I have written this as “heir” not “hair”. These lines refer to King David’s adulterous relationship in later life with Bathsheba. See here ->Bible Gateway passage: 2 Samuel 11 David being a holy man of faith became king because of his good character and favor with the lord - but he fell from God’s graces and was severely punished for his sins after he saw a married women Bathsheba bathing from his palace rooftop. He called for her, and despite the fact she was married to a soldier under his command - Uriah - he had sex with her and got her pregnant. He then arranged to have her husband Uriah sent to the front of the battle lines so he would be killed and he could take her as his wife. After doing this she then went on to bear his first son. As punishment from God for these deeds his kingdom fell into civil war, his first born child was then struck down ill and died - and eventually someone close to him later claimed himself as king forced him from the city and had relations with his wives in public view. Thus the breaking of his throne and cutting of his “heir”: the first born “heir” to his throne and kingdom, not “hair” on his head as in the story of Samson. Sam 2:13 - Nathan replied, “The Lord has taken away your sin. You are not going to die. But because by doing this you have shown utter contempt for the Lord, the son born to you will die.” After Nathan had gone home, the Lord struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill. David pleaded with God for the child. He fasted and spent the nights lying in sackcloth on the ground. The elders of his household stood beside him to get him up from the ground, but he refused, and he would not eat any food with them. On the seventh day the child died. When taking this biblical context the “From his lips she drew the Hallelujah” - is not so much about sexual orgasm but more so about how she tempted him into sinful actions which resulted in him falling into ruin and despair. There he once again found god - this time instead of through righteous holy action as he had done previously in his early life - it was through forgiveness, mercy and restoration from god when he was a broken man. (See David’s plea to god for forgiveness -Psalm 51 - Bible Gateway passage: Psalm 51 - English Standard Version). Thus the following lines indicated the different paths David followed to find God. It doesn’t matter which you heard The holy or the broken Hallelujah.

Generally, this is a song about heartbreak and bitterness. Verse by verse: Well I've heard there was a secret chordThat David played and it pleased the Lord King David, from the old testament of the Bible, was known to be a harp player and often wrote spiritual music, though no specific chord was referenced.But you don't really care for music, do you?Well it goes like this:The fourth, the fifth, the minor fall and the major lift The chords in this part of the song are literally the fourth and fifth in the Key of C, followed by a descending minor and ascending major.The baffled king composing Hallelujah Well your faith was strong but you needed proofYou saw her bathing on the roof Her beauty and the moonlight overthrew yaShe tied you to her kitchen chairAnd she broke your throne and she cut your hairAnd from your lips she drew the Hallelujah again talking about King David, and how he saw a woman named Bathsheba. he wanted her, but she was married. So, he sent her husband off to war where he died, and David married Bathsheba. God punished him for such selfish behavior throughout the rest of his life But baby I've been here beforeI've seen this room and I've walked this floorYou know, I used to live alone before I knew yaAnd I've seen your flag on the marble archAnd love is not a victory marchIt's a cold and it's a broken Hallelujah Commenting on a love that’s over, bitterness and being jaded when it comes to love. Well there was a time when you let me knowWhat's really going on belowBut now you never show that to me do yaBut remember when I moved in youAnd the holy dove was moving tooAnd every breath we drew was Hallelujah The singer misses having conjugal relations with a someone. Maybe there's a God aboveBut all I've ever learned from loveWas how to shoot somebody who outdrew yaAnd it's not a cry that you hear at nightIt's not somebody who's seen the lightIt's a cold and it's a broken Hallelujah The Singer doesn’t see the point in love if it only causes pain and betrayal.

There are so many layers of meaning, it's hard to know where to start to interpret it. But here's a stab. I won't reiterate the verses, just state what they mean to me. I also tend to take the view that it's about saying yes to life, in all its wretchedness and beauty, and thanking God for all of it, that's why it doesn't matter which “Hallelujah” you heard, the holy or the broken. They're the same in intensity. Possibly the broken one is even holier, because it's easy to sing praise in rapture and pleasure, like when you're in love. It's much harder to see beauty in suffering when the love is over. Many Eastern religions don't see suffering as “bad”, it's merely another interesting experience for the spirit. So everything is Hallelujah. The overall tone of the song, however, is plaintive and brokenhearted. It seems he wrote it from the broken place, in the wake of love. So it feels more like a weary surrender, an awed, humbled and indeed “baffled” attitude toward the mysterious ways of love and God. And I don't think it's sacrilegious to point this out, but it's definitely about sex too. Absolutely. Being a master poet, he made numerous lines ambiguous, so they could be read as either about religion or sex. I see them as both at once. This is a big part of what makes the song so effective. Instead of drawing a distinction between sacred and profane, he elevates the profane aspects into sacred territory. When every breath they drew was Hallelujah, the Holy Ghost was present for their union, it was consecrated. It was a religious experience. This evokes Tantra, Maithuna, Song of Solomon, sex as a sacred act. There are many ways to experience “Hallelujah” the feeling, the mystery and awe that drives you to your knees and draws praise to your lips. Sex is a valid route. So is music. Many musicians describe the creative act as “their church”, something supernatural speaking through them that they don't fully understand. Apparently David was in touch with this. At his humblest, he was a lightning rod for the divine. Cohen recognized God in all these things. This song interleaves the love beween a man and a woman with the love between mankind and  God. The word Halleluja is the thread that binds these themes.  This is not a traditional love song or a hymn. It comes from a place of great pain, love turned sour, and from a broken man who questions God.  The woman is a believer in the ideals of love and faith. The singer is not. There is an antagonistic tone between the man and the woman from the start of the song. He feels that she has a idealistic and rosy view of love and faith. She feels he does not truly believe in either.  Yet at one time the lovers were engulfed in an intense love. Now the singer feels he was seduced and consumed by a force greater than himself. In their love he saw the divine, in their love he saw his destruction.   To her the word Hallelujah is joyous and uttered from a place of faith. To him Hallelujah comes from a place that is "cold and broken." The key line of the whole song elevates this theme to a higher metaphysical level:   "There's a blaze of light in every word It doesn't matter which you heard The holy or the broken Hallelujah" To Cohen "light" is loaded with layers of metaphysical meaning. We come full circle to the introduction of the song, which references the biblical David's "secret chord" that "pleased the Lord" and the seductress Delilah.  The light is the spark of the divine. And it is in "every word". Words are the key unit of our human experience. They are imperfect for expressing it, but they are all we have. Words give our souls a means to speak to the world. Great lyrics like these are more than the sum of their words. They strike a chord. This is the same "Light" Cohen sings of in "Anthem:"  Ring the bells that still can ring Forget your perfect offering There is a crack, a crack in everything That's how the light gets in. That's how the light gets in. That's how the light gets in.  What did Leonard Cohen mean by:"There is a crack, a crack in everythingThat's how the light gets in"? The whole of experience is divine, the triumphs and the destitution. There is no difference between cursing and praising God. As long as we face love and loss with our hearts and minds open to the infinite possibility of the moment we are participating in the divine. (Note: the Jeff Buckley version left out some of the key metaphysical lyrics)

"Hallelujah" was first released in 1984 as part of Cohen's album "Various Pleasures." Cohen wrote over 80 verses to the song before eventually trimming the lyrics down to the four verses heard in the final version. The song contains numerous allusions to Biblical figures, such as King David, and juxtaposes religious sentiment with dry, ironic humor. The song has been described as being about the frustration of songwriting itself and Cohen's personal frustration with the commercial failure of his previous records, despite critical acclaim. The song remained relatively obscure until a cover version by Jeff Buckley, released posthumously, became a smash success. Since then, "Hallelujah" has frequently been used in movies and TV shows, such as "Shrek" and "The West Wing," and it is often played at private gatherings, such as weddings and funerals. Other artists who have covered the song include John Cale, Amanda Palmer, Willie Nelson and Bono. "Hallelujah" has become one of the most covered songs in the world, though different artists often perform the song with less cynicism than Cohen Signature: HaThu

Here are some quotes from Leonard Cohen that may shed some light on this question and give us some interesting perspectives about the meaning of this song: “I wanted to get into this tradition of the composers who said “Hallelujah”, but with no precisely religious point of view.” “It’s, as I say, a desire to affirm my faith in life, not in some formal religious way, but with enthusiasm, with emotion” (Leonard Cohen interview, 1985). “I wanted to write something in the tradition of the hallelujah choruses but from a different point of view”(Leonard Cohen interview, 1995). The traditional “Hallelujah” is an ancient word of prayer, used for expressing a person’s or a nation’s gratitude, love and loyalty to their lord – calling out: “Let’s all praise the lord”. Cohen wanted to be – in some way – a continuer of this tradition, although it would be independent of any religious framework .Cohen has a new way, a new meaning for the “Hallelujah”. He wants to call out his own “Hallelujah” to the Lord, to the world and to life. “There is a religious Hallelujah, but there are many other ones .When one looks at the world and his proper life there’s only one thing to say, it is ‘Hallelujah’ “. “The Hallelujah, the David’s Hallelujah, was still a religious song. So I wanted to indicate that Hallelujah can come out of things that have nothing to do with religion”. “And then I realize there is a Hallelujah more general that we speak to the world, to life”. (Leonard Cohen interviews, 1985 – 1988)

It’s about the Jewish relationship with God. Leonard was raised and lived - despite immersing himself in a number of religions - mostly as an Orthodox Jew. The Orthodox name for God is ‘HaShem’, which literally means The Name, which is the reference in the 3rd verse to you say I used the name in vain but I don’t even know the name’. He’s saying he can’t know God. In the Jewish conception, you can’t know the mind of God, can’t conceive of God except to say that God is beyond conception. The point as a song is that by torturing David with Bathsheba, God creates through David the great devotional Hallelujah, and that he, meaning Leonard, tries but fails and yet he’ll keep trying so he will in the end stand before HaShem with nothing in his mind, nothing on his tongue but the great devotional Hallelujah drawn out of human longing, lust and love for human and spiritual connection.
